applicationName: Health Care Partners of South Carolina, Inc._Application-242773.pdf
extractedContent:
Application Number: 242773
Filename: Health Care Partners of South Carolina, Inc._Application-242773.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-23T05:05:45.526Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence: In the Project Narrative, under '5. Describe how you will: a. Conduct and update your needs assessment:', the applicant states: 'HCPSC conducts a Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) every three years, or more if deemed necessary by the Board of Directors. HCPSC utilizes primary data whenever possible and utilizes data from other local health assessments and state data sources to determine and prioritize health service needs and socio-environmental issues from the perspectives of key stakeholders in the local community HCPSC serves.' The application further details in the 'NEED' section that the most recent needs assessment was completed, and UDS data from 2022-2024 is referenced throughout the needs assessment narrative. The application describes how the needs assessment is used to inform service delivery, including annual reviews of patient zip code analysis, health disparities, and collaborative discussions. The application also describes how patient and community input is used to inform the needs assessment and service delivery, including patient board members and patient surveys. The application provides detailed data tables and references to current data sources (UDS, County Health Rankings, HRSA tools, etc.).
compliantItems.reasoning: The applicant demonstrates that a needs assessment is completed at least every three years, as required, and that it is updated with the most recently available data. The narrative describes how the assessment is used to inform and improve service delivery, and references to current data and ongoing annual reviews are provided. The process includes both quantitative and qualitative data, and the needs assessment is used to align services with community needs. There is clear evidence of compliance with the requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13: Health Center Compliance states: 'It is the policy of Health Care Partners of South Carolina (HCPSC) to provide a Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) that assures that the health center's scope of project, as noted in UDS Form 5, Services, regardless of their ability to pay, while allowing the health center to maximize reasonable revenue sources. The SFDP is based solely on family size and income for all patients. Patients or Guarantors may apply for SFDP regardless of insured status. No discounts are provided to individuals or families with incomes above 200% of the Federal Poverty Guideline (FPG).' The policy is reviewed and approved by the Board of Directors at least annually (Attachment 13: 'HCPSC's Board of Directors reviews the Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS) policy at least annually...'). The Bylaws (Attachment 2) confirm the Board's authority over policies. The policy addresses definitions of income and family, annual review, and application process, and is described as applying uniformly to all patients.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a board-approved policy, reviewed annually, that applies to all patients regardless of insurance status, and addresses required areas (definitions, annual review, application process, etc.). The policy is referenced in both the compliance narrative and the bylaws, and the sliding fee discount schedule is included as Attachment 10. There is no evidence of exclusion or non-uniform application.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 5A: Services Provided shows that required services (General Primary Medical Care, Diagnostic Laboratory, Screenings, Well Child Services, Gynecological Care, Preventive Dental, Pharmaceutical Services, Case Management, Eligibility Assistance, Health Education, Outreach, Transportation, Translation, etc.) are provided directly (Column I). The Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (Attachment 10) is structured with discount levels A-D for 0-200% FPG and self-pay above 200%, with nominal fee for ≤100% FPG. The narrative (Project Narrative, p. 22; Attachment 13) describes that 'No patient is ever turned away due to an inability to pay for care at HCPSC. HCPSC adjusted patient charges based on the ability to pay, as depicted in Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule.' The policy is applied to all services provided directly (Column I).
compliantItems.reasoning: The evidence shows that the sliding fee discount schedule is applied to all required Column I services, with discounts structured according to income and family size, and a nominal fee for those ≤100% FPG. The application narrative and compliance attachment confirm that the SFDS is consistent with policy and is applied to all direct services, as required.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule is based on the 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG), as shown by the income thresholds listed for each family size and scale. Attachment 13 states: 'HCPSC's Board of Directors reviews the Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS) policy at least annually and aligns the sliding fee schedule annually with the current FPG. The Board of Directors permits the CFO to make the appropriate Federal Poverty Guideline changes to the sliding fee scale on the day of the release of the FPG. The most recent review of both the SFDS and its policy was completed in October of 2024.' The Project Narrative (p. 22) also confirms annual updates.
compliantItems.reasoning: The sliding fee schedule provided is based on the most recent FPG, and the policy and compliance narrative confirm that the schedule is updated annually upon release of new FPGs, with Board approval. The evidence is clear and current.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff provides detailed position descriptions for the CEO, CFO, and CMO, including duties, responsibilities, reporting relationships, evaluation, and required qualifications/education/experience. Attachment 5: Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff provides the training and experience for each key management staff member. The Project Narrative (CAPACITY section) references these attachments and summarizes the qualifications and roles of the CEO, CFO, and CMO. Form 2: Staffing Profile lists the key management staff and their FTEs.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application includes both detailed position descriptions (duties/functions, required qualifications) and biographical sketches (actual training and experience) for each key management staff position, as required. The documentation is referenced in the narrative and provided in the attachments, meeting the HRSA requirement for this element.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff (CEO) states the CEO is responsible for day-to-day management, reports directly to the Board of Directors, and supervises the executive management team. The Project Narrative (CAPACITY section) confirms the CEO is a full-time employee (1.0 FTE) of HCPSC, directly employed by the health center, and reports to the Board. The Organizational Chart (Attachment 3) shows the CEO at the top, reporting to the Board, and supervising other key management staff. The Bylaws (Attachment 2, Article III, Section 1.e and Article V, Section 9) specify the Board hires, evaluates, and terminates the CEO, and the CEO directs all operations and supervises all personnel. Form 2: Staffing Profile lists the CEO as a direct hire (1.0 FTE).
compliantItems.reasoning: There is clear, consistent evidence that the CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the governing board, and is responsible for overseeing key management staff and daily operations. The documentation is found in the position description, organizational chart, bylaws, staffing profile, and narrative, fully meeting HRSA requirements for this element.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements details contracts with LabCorp, Conway Medical Center, MUSC, McLeod Hospital, Waccamaw Center for Mental Health, Jeenie Healthcare Interpretation Service, and Equiscript (340B). The compliance narrative in Attachment 13 states: 'Board-approved policies ensure the proper procurement and oversight of all contracted services, including provisions for monitoring and evaluating contractor performance by the board and management team.' It further states, 'The Board of Directors and management team have implemented policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the terms, conditions, and requirements of grant awards. The Board of Directors and leadership team ensure that the terms of all agreements are adhered to. HCPSC requires that contractors or sub-recipients provide supporting documentation, including purchase orders, invoices, and justification for any expenditure, before any funds are distributed to the contractor. In addition, HCPSC requires regular financial and performance reports.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a detailed list of contracts supporting the HRSA-approved scope of project and describes board-approved policies for procurement, oversight, and monitoring. It also references compliance with federal requirements and cost principles. This meets the requirement for contract provisions.

nonCompliantItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
nonCompliantItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
nonCompliantItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
nonCompliantItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Question 2a: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'Not applicable. While HCPSC may establish contracts for formal referral processes to local hospitals, FQHCs, and health departments (see Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements), these agencies will not be a subrecipient of HCPSC or a co-applicant.' However, Form 5A shows that some required services (e.g., diagnostic radiology, obstetrical care) are provided via formal written contracts/agreements (Column II), and the contracts in Attachment 7 are for clinical services (e.g., diagnostic radiology, obstetrical care, mental health).
nonCompliantItems.reasoning: The application asserts that there are no contracts for substantive programmatic work, but Form 5A and Attachment 7 show that some required clinical services are provided via contract. HRSA defines 'substantive programmatic work' as contracting with a single entity for the majority of health care providers, but also expects prior approval for contracts that cover a substantial portion of required services. The application does not provide documentation of HRSA prior approval for these contracts, nor does it provide a clear rationale for why these contracts do not require such approval. Therefore, the requirement is not met.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'Not applicable. While HCPSC may establish contracts for formal referral processes to local hospitals, FQHCs, and health departments (see Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements), these agencies will not be a subrecipient of HCPSC or a co-applicant.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center does not utilize subawards to carry out any portion of the scope of project. There are no subrecipients. Therefore, this requirement is not applicable.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'Not applicable. While HCPSC may establish contracts for formal referral processes to local hospitals, FQHCs, and health departments (see Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements), these agencies will not be a subrecipient of HCPSC or a co-applicant.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center does not utilize subawards. There are no subrecipients. Therefore, this requirement is not applicable.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The application narrative (COLLABORATION section, Project Narrative p. 25-28) details collaborations with local hospitals (Conway Medical Center, Medical University of South Carolina, McLeod Hospital), specialty providers (LabCorp, Equiscript, Jeenie Healthcare Interpretation Service), and social service organizations (Pee Dee Community Action Partnership, AccessHealth Horry, Mason Temple Church, South Carolina Department of Public Health). Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements lists formal contracts with these entities for services not available at the health center (e.g., diagnostic radiology, mammography, obstetrical care, mental health). Multiple letters of support from these partners are included in Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation. The narrative also describes referral and follow-up processes, and the use of patient care coordinators to ensure access and continuity.
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center provides extensive documentation of active collaborations with a broad range of providers and organizations in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service agencies. These collaborations are formalized through contracts and referral agreements, and are supported by letters of support. The application describes how these relationships provide access to services not available directly through the health center, such as specialty care, diagnostic imaging, and social support services. The evidence is robust and meets HRSA's requirements for this element.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The COLLABORATION section of the Project Narrative (p. 25-28) and Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation provide evidence of active relationships with other HRSA-funded health centers in the service area, including Little River Medical Center, HopeHealth, and CareSouth Carolina. Letters of support from these FQHCs are included, specifically referencing ongoing partnerships for prenatal, postpartum, and delivery care, as well as general collaboration to improve population health. There is also a letter from Careteam Plus, an FQHC look-alike, describing longstanding collaboration. The application describes efforts to obtain letters of support, and includes documentation of outreach to other providers. The narrative also describes collaboration with the South Carolina Primary Health Care Association (PCA) and participation in the Health Center Controlled Network (HCCN).
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center provides clear documentation of relationships with other federally-funded health centers in the service area, supported by multiple letters of support and descriptions of collaborative activities. The application also addresses collaboration with the state PCA and HCCN. The evidence demonstrates compliance with HRSA's requirement to coordinate and integrate activities with other primary care providers serving similar populations.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence:
1. Attachment 13: Health Center Compliance, 'Billing and Collections' section: 'HCPSC participates in Medicare, Medicaid, and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). Before requesting reimbursement through Medicaid, CHIP, or Medicare, third-party private insurance companies are billed the full, usual, and customary, board-approved fee for all applicable services.'
2. Form 3 - Income Analysis: Medicaid, Medicare, Private, and Self Pay are all listed as payer categories with projected patient numbers and income.
3. Project Narrative: 'HCPSC provides all services on a sliding scale, ensuring that financial strain is not a barrier to receiving services through the health center and does not turn away patients due to inability to pay. ... HCPSC also accepts private insurance, Medicare and Medicaid to ensure accessibility further.'
4. Letters of support and outreach documentation (Att9) reference acceptance of Medicaid, Medicare, and private insurance.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides multiple, consistent references to active participation in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and private insurance programs. These are supported by narrative, compliance documentation, and financial projections, as well as external letters of support. The center also describes eligibility assistance for these programs. There is no evidence of exclusion or non-participation. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence:
1. Attachment 13: Health Center Compliance, 'Billing and Collections' section: 'It is the policy of HCPSC to ensure that all patients have access to all services within HCPSC's scope of project. No patient will be denied services due to their inability to pay. HCPSC will offer a Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) for health care services uniformly to all patients. In addition to the sliding fee discount schedule, HCPSC will work with patients to offer additional billing options or payment methods (i.e., payment plans and grace periods) if needed to ensure that payments are affordable and will be made in a timely manner. HCPSC has operating procedures in place for implementing these options and for ensuring they are accessible to all patients, regardless of income level or SFDS pay class. ... there may be certain situations that warrant waiving a portion of, or all, the fees. Patients reporting an inability to pay their assessed fee for service may be reassessed by staff to verify the inability and a possible request for fee reduction based on diagnostic and financial criteria. Support staff may submit a request for a fee reduction, accompanied by a written assessment of the patient's diagnosis, duration, income, expenses, dependents, risk of relapse, and any extenuating circumstances that would prevent the patient from receiving needed services without a fee reduction. ... Staff are trained to send patients who have experienced or are experiencing a hardship circumstance or event to the eligibility assistance team. The eligibility assistance team can determine and complete applicable hardship documentation. Hardship events include, but are not limited to, the following: job loss, house fire, natural disaster, loss of health insurance, work lay-off, and catastrophic family loss.'
2. Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule and narrative in Project Narrative and Compliance Attachment confirm board approval and annual review.
3. Form 1C - Documents On File confirms the presence of 'Billing and Collections policies/procedures, including those regarding waivers or fee reductions and refusal to pay.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides detailed, board-approved policies and procedures for waiving or reducing fees, including specific circumstances (e.g., hardship events, financial/diagnostic criteria) and a process for staff to request fee reductions. The policies are reviewed and approved by the board annually. There is clear evidence that these policies are in place, utilized, and accessible to patients. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The application includes a detailed SF-424A: Budget Information - Non-Construction Programs, a Budget Narrative, and a Budget Justification. The total budget is $30,545,873 ($3,461,224 federal, $27,084,649 non-federal), with line-item breakdowns for personnel, fringe, travel, equipment, supplies, contractual, and other. The budget narrative explicitly states: 'HCPSC will use the requested $3,461,224 Federal funds to provide comprehensive, high-quality primary health care services to underserved communities and populations in the SAAT designated Conway, South Carolina service area (SAC ID 161).' The budget aligns with the scope of services and projected patient volume (17,125 in 2026), as reflected in Forms 1A, 3, 5A, 5B, and the Project Narrative.
compliantItems.reasoning: The budget is comprehensive, aligns with the HRSA-approved scope of project, and is consistent across all required documents. It includes both costs and revenues, supports the projected patient and visit numbers, and is tied to the full scope of services and sites. The application narrative, budget forms, and budget narrative all confirm that the budget is developed and submitted to HRSA and reflects the necessary resources for the proposed scope of project.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A, Budget Narrative, and Form 3: Income Analysis all provide a breakdown of revenue sources. The budget shows $3,461,224 in federal HRSA funds and $27,084,649 in non-federal funds, which are further detailed as program income ($25,984,649), private grants/contracts ($800,000), and other income (interest, contributions, patient medical record revenue, $300,000). Form 3: Income Analysis details projected income by payer (Medicaid, Medicare, Private, Self Pay) and other sources. The narrative states: 'Consistent with the SF-424A, Budget Narrative, Form 2: Staffing Profile, and Form 3: Income Analysis, HCPSC has submitted a complete, consistent, and detailed budget for the requested federal funds of $3,461,224.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application clearly identifies and quantifies all revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, including federal, program income (from patient services by payer), private grants/contracts, and other sources. The revenue sources are consistent across all budget documents and are sufficient to support the proposed scope of project. This meets the HRSA requirement for inclusion of all revenue sources in the annual budget.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article III, Section 1.b states: 'Overseeing of the Corporation's Health Center Program Project and that no other individual, entity or committee (including but not limited to, an executive committee authorized by the Board) may reserve approval authority or have veto power over the Board with regard to the required authorities and functions.' Attachment 13: Health Center Compliance reiterates this provision. The Project Narrative and Compliance Narrative both state that the Board of Directors has overall control, including legal and fiduciary responsibility for the operations of the health center, and that the CEO reports directly to the Board. Form 8 confirms there are no parent, affiliate, or subsidiary organizations, and no subrecipient or programmatic contracts that would restrict board authority.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly state that the Board has full authority over the Health Center Program project and that no other entity or committee can reserve approval authority or have veto power over the Board with respect to required authorities and functions. The organizational chart and narrative confirm the Board's oversight, and there are no relationships or agreements that would infringe on this authority. This meets HRSA's requirement for maintenance of board authority.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article III, Section 1 lists required authorities and responsibilities, including: (a) developing, adopting, and updating bylaws; (c) conducting monthly meetings; (d) identifying health center priorities and strategic planning; (e) hiring, evaluating, and terminating the CEO; (f) developing/adopting policies; (g) developing/adopting personnel policies; (h) developing/adopting financial management practices; (i) developing/adopting operational policies (scope, sites, hours, confidentiality, QI/QA); (j) reviewing/approving annual budget and grant applications; (k) selecting the auditor and accepting annual reports; (l) evaluating health center activities; (m) resolving patient grievances; (n) assuring compliance with laws/regulations; (o) assuring services are responsive to community needs; (p) approving subawards/contracts for substantial services; (q) developing/adopting billing and collections policies. Attachment 13: Health Center Compliance cross-references these sections, and the Project Narrative describes board activities consistent with these authorities. Form 6A confirms board composition and patient-majority requirements.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws enumerate all required authorities and responsibilities as specified by HRSA, including those related to strategic direction, policy adoption, CEO oversight, budget approval, evaluation of health center performance, and compliance. The application narrative and compliance attachment confirm that these authorities are implemented in practice. There is no evidence of any restriction or omission of required board authorities. Therefore, this element is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article III, Sections 3, 6, 7, and Article IV, Section 8, outline the nomination, election, resignation, and removal of directors. Article III, Section 1.b states: 'no other individual, entity or committee (including but not limited to, an executive committee authorized by the Board) may reserve approval authority or have veto power over the Board with regard to the required authorities and functions.' Article III, Section 7 further states: 'Board of Director selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee, or individual (other than the HCPSC Board) to select either the Board Chairperson or the majority of the Corporation's Health Center Board Directors, including a majority of the non-consumer Board Directors.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly specify the process for selection and removal of board members, including nomination, election, and removal by the board itself. The bylaws explicitly prohibit any other entity, committee, or individual from selecting the board chair or the majority of board members, including non-patient members. This meets the HRSA requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article III, Section 4: 'The Board of Directors shall consist of at least nine and no more than twenty-five persons.' Article III, Section 5: 'At least fifty one percent of the Directors must be consumers that utilize the services of the Corporation's Health Center as their medical or dental home.' Section 5 also requires non-consumer directors to complement consumers in technical expertise and to be representative of the community by living or working in the community. No more than one half of the non-consumer directors may earn more than 10% of their income from the healthcare industry. Article III, Section 4 also prohibits employees or relatives of employees from serving as directors.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws specify all required board composition elements: minimum and maximum size, at least 51% patient/consumer members, representation of the community, relevant expertise among non-patient members, and restrictions on employees and their relatives. This is fully compliant with HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A - Current Board Member Characteristics lists 11 board members. 9 of 11 are health center patients. All but two live or work in the service area. No board member earns more than 10% of income from the health industry. Areas of expertise include education, business, banking, dentistry, government, veteran services, insurance, and Hispanic advocacy. The board includes both patient and non-patient members, with non-patient members providing relevant expertise.
compliantItems.reasoning: The current board composition matches the requirements: at least 9 members, at least 51% patients (9 of 11), non-patient members with relevant expertise, and representation of the community served. There are no employees or immediate family members of employees on the board. This is compliant.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B - Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' The application only requests 330(e) (CHC) funding and does not request 330(g), 330(h), or 330(i) funding.
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The applicant is not requesting a waiver and is not applying for funding under 330(g), 330(h), or 330(i) only. Therefore, this requirement is not applicable.
